intro: Sarcolobus secamonoides, commonly known as the Indian spurge, is a flowering plant native to the Indian subcontinent. It belongs to the family Euphorbiaceae and is characterized by its milky latex sap, which is a common feature among members of this family. The plant typically grows as a shrub, featuring simple, alternate leaves and small, clustered flowers. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often found in moist, well-drained soils. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and traditional medicine practices.
